importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: Diwali is celebrated on this date, marking the start of the festival of lights and cultural unity among South Asian communities worldwide.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The five-day Diwali festival spans from October 20 to October 25, with key traditions observed across multiple days, reflecting cultural continuity and community celebration.

keyTakeAways: Diwali is a major cultural and religious festival celebrated by over a billion Hindus, Sikhs, Jains, and Buddhists globally.
The festival marks the triumph of light over darkness and good over evil, with different regional and religious interpretations.
Diwali is celebrated on October 20, 2025, and spans five days: Dhanteras, Choti Diwali, Diwali (Lakshmi Puja), Padwa (Govardhan Puja), and Bhai Dooj.

Each day has unique traditions: Dhanteras involves purchasing gold and silver for good luck; Choti Diwali celebrates Lord Krishna’s victory over Narakasura; Diwali features Lakshmi Puja and family feasting; Padwa honors marital bonds; Bhai Dooj celebrates sibling love.
The festival has deep mythological roots, including the Ramayana story of Rama’s return from exile, the defeat of demon king Bali, and Lord Mahavira’s enlightenment.
Sikhs commemorate Diwali as Bandi Chhor Divas, marking the liberation of Guru Hargobind and 52 kings from imprisonment.
Jains celebrate it as the day of Lord Mahavira’s enlightenment, while some Buddhists recognize it as the day Emperor Ashoka embraced Buddhism.
Diwali is increasingly celebrated as a cultural holiday, transcending religious boundaries and uniting diverse communities through shared traditions like lighting diyas, fireworks, and feasting.
The festival also marks the beginning of the new Hindu financial year and is associated with business openings and gambling (e.g., teen patti) in some regions.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Diwali, the festival of lights, is celebrated globally by over a billion Hindus, Sikhs, Jains, and Buddhists on October 20, 2025. Rooted in ancient myths such as the Ramayana and stories of Krishna’s victory over demons, Diwali symbolizes the triumph of light over darkness and good over evil. The festival spans five days, each with unique traditions: Dhanteras (buying gold and silver), Choti Diwali (Krishna’s victory over Narakasura), Diwali (Lakshmi Puja and family feasting), Padwa (marital bonds and Govardhan Hill), and Bhai Dooj (sibling love). While religious in origin, Diwali has become a cultural celebration, transcending faith to unite communities through shared rituals like lighting diyas, fireworks, and feasting. The festival also marks the start of the new Hindu financial year and includes unique historical narratives such as the Sikh Bandi Chhor Divas (liberation of Guru Hargobind and 52 kings) and the Jain celebration of Lord Mahavira’s enlightenment. These diverse interpretations highlight Diwali’s role as a unifying, spiritually rich, and culturally vibrant global event.
title: It’s Diwali, a time for light, community and fresh starts
